reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central part of the essay’s optimism about “trade/compromise” routes to mostly-great futures: the idea (3.3–3.4) that preventing value-destroying threats is a broadly desirable, cross-view stabilizing move. If that is undermined, the trade-based path looks substantially less promising, though the overall essay has other pillars (e.g., pessimism about WAM-convergence) and already flags that stable threat-prevention may be hard, so the attacked claim isn’t fully load-bearing (hence centrality ~0.6). The critique has real force: if some agents have strongly unbounded/lexicographic objectives, they may rationally invest in coercive tactics and interpret “anti-threat regimes” as adversarial constraints, potentially selecting for escalation/obfuscation and undermining compromise. However, it overstates by implying threatening is “the” dominant strategy for unbounded objectives: profitability/dominance depends on credibility, cost, counter-threats, enforcement tech, equilibrium selection, and whether “unbounded” is actually lexicographic or merely non-satiating. Also the essay already anticipates parts of this (“not obvious… prevents threats… mutually agreeable and stable”), reducing marginal refutation. The critique is mostly clear and focused with little fluff; main ambiguity is that it assumes a particular optimizer/game-theoretic model and collapses several cases (unbounded, linear, lexicographic) into one.
title: Threat prevention regimes may escalate conflict with unbounded-utility agents
